lines.text: Enter the Earls of SOMERSET, SUFFOLK, and WARWICK RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another Lawyer

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence Dare no man answer in a case of truth

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Within the Templehall we were too loud The garden here is more convenient. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Then say at once if I maintaind the truth Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Faith, I have been a truant in the law, And never yet could frame my will to it And therefore frame the law unto my will.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth Between two blades, which bears the better temper: Between two horses, which doth bear him best Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement But in these nice sharp quillets of the law, Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance: The truth appears so naked on my side That any purblind eye may find it out.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: And on my side it is so well apparelld, So clear, so shining and so evident That it will glimmer through a blind mans eye. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Since you are tonguetied and so loath to speak, In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts: Let him that is a trueborn gentleman And stands upon the honour of his birth, If he suppose that I have pleaded truth, From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer, But dare maintain the party of the truth, Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: I love no colours, and without all colour Of base insinuating flattery I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset And say withal I think he held the right.

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more, Till you conclude that he upon whose side The fewest roses are croppd from the tree Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected: If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: And I.

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: Then for the truth and plainness of the case. I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here, Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off, Lest bleeding you do paint the white rose red And fall on my side so, against your will.

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: If I my lord, for my opinion bleed, Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt And keep me on the side where still I am.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Well, well, come on: who else

lines.speaker: lawyer
lines.text: Unless my study and my books be false, The argument you held was wrong in you: In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too. RICHARD
To SOMERSET

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Now, Somerset, where is your argument

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Here in my scabbard, meditating that Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses For pale they look with fear, as witnessing The truth on our side.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: No, Plantagenet, Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses, And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Well, Ill find friends to wear my bleeding roses, That shall maintain what I have said is true, Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand, I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Ill turn my part thereof into thy throat.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Away, away, good William de la Pole! We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Now, by Gods will, thou wrongst him, Somerset His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence, Third son to the third Edward King of England: Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: He bears him on the places privilege, Or durst not, for his craven heart, say thus.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: By him that made me, Ill maintain my words On any plot of ground in Christendom. Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge, For treason executed in our late kings days And, by his treason, standst not thou attainted, Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: My father was attached, not attainted, Condemnd to die for treason, but no traitor And that Ill prove on better men than Somerset, Were growing time once ripend to my will. For your partaker Pole and you yourself, Ill note you in my book of memory, To scourge you for this apprehension: Look to it well and say you are well warnd.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still And know us by these colours for thy foes, For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose, As cognizance of my blooddrinking hate, Will I for ever and my faction wear, Until it wither with me to my grave Or flourish to the height of my degree.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Go forward and be choked with thy ambition! And so farewell until I meet thee next.
Exit

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard. RICHARD
Exit

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: This blot that they object against your house Shall be wiped out in the next parliament Calld for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester And if thou be not then created York, I will not live to be accounted Warwick. Meantime, in signal of my love to thee, Against proud Somerset and William Pole, Will I upon thy party wear this rose: And here I prophesy: this brawl today, Grown to this faction in the Templegarden, Shall send between the red rose and the white A thousand souls to death and deadly night. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you, That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

lines.speaker: lawyer
lines.text: And so will I. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Thanks, gentle sir. Come, let us four to dinner: I dare say This quarrel will drink blood another day.
Exeunt
